[[File:Real Galley Replica Barcelona.jpg|thumb|300px|A replica of a Spanish Galley in Barcelona.]] The '''''Bazana''''' (often called '''''Vasana''''' in older English sources) was a [[galley]] which was a part of the [[Spanish Armada]] of 1588. It played a minor and relatively unremarkable part in the campaign: whilst passing through the [[Bay of Biscay]] the fleet was hit by a [[Storm|tempest]], forcing the four lightly built ships of the galley squadron to take shelter in French ports. One galley, the ''Diana'', ran aground in the harbour entrance at [[Bayonne]], but the crew, including the [[galley slave]]s who rowed the ship, were rescued; the ''Bazana'' and the other two ships took around ten days to repair their storm damage, and subsequently returned to Spain.
The ''Bazana'' owes its fame to a highly fictitionalized account of its fate associated with [[David Gwynne (Sailor)|David Gwynne]], a Welsh prisoner who was forced to serve in the Armada as a galley slave. According to this version, the ''Diana'' sank with the loss of all hands when the squadron were still far from port, and the captain of the ''Bazana'' appealed to Gwynne's skill as a seaman in the hope that he could save the ship; Gwynne exploited the situation to get the slaves freed from their shackles, enabling them to kill the Spanish crew and seize the ship using homemade [[stilettos]]. Next, this version claims, another galley, the ''Royal'' (i.e. the ''Capitana'' or flagship), attempted to attack them, but Gwynne and the other freed slaves boarded the larger ship, massacred the second Spanish crew and sailed both ships to Bayonne. Gwynne's story was popularized as a propaganda in the [[Dutch Revolt]], and came to be treated as fact by many English historians of the nineteenth century, inspiring [[Theodore Watts-Dunton]] in, ''The Jubilee Greeting at Spithead to the Men of Greater Britain''.<ref name="Shippen, Edward 1">Shippen pp. 90-91</ref><ref name="Beeton, Samuel Orchart 1">Beeton p. 456</ref><ref name="Hake, Thomas 1">Hake p. 285</ref>
The reality was exposed in the 1880s by the Spanish naval historian ''Capitan de Navio'' Cesáreo Fernández Duro, who argued that Gwynn was even aboard the ''Diana'' rather than the ''Bazana'': he and some other English galley slaves simply absconded, or were allowed to depart, after the squadron reached harbour in France. Duro's findings were communicated to the English audience by Prof. Sir [[John Knox Laughton]] in 1894.<ref name="Laughton, Sir J.K. 1">Laughton, Introduction, pp. lxxvii-lxxix, citing Duro i. 65, ii. 279.</ref> Most detailed modern histories of the Armada campaign make a point of refuting the fictions.<ref name="Howard, David 1">Howarth, pp. 112-113.</ref><ref name="Mattingly, Garret 1">Mattingly, pp. 269-70.</ref><ref name="Hart Davis, Duff 1">Hart-Davis, p. 93.</ref>
A galley named ''Bazana'' subsequently participated in the Spanish victory in the [[Battle of Cornwall]] in 1595.<ref name="Martínez, Ricardo Cerezo 1">Martínez, p. 400.</ref>
